titleStmt.title: The History of Van brugh's House

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: When mother Clud had rose from play
And call'd to take the Cards away,
Van saw but seem'd not to regard
How Miss pick't ev'ry painted card
And busy both with hand, and Eye
Soon rear'd a House two Story's high
Van's Genius (wthout thought or Lecture)
This highly turn'd to Architecture,
He Saw the Edifice, and smil'd
Vow'd it was pretty for a Child,
It was so perfect in it's kind
He kept the Model in his mind
But when he found the Boys at play
And Saw them dabbling in their Clay
He Stood behind a Stall to lurk
And mark the Progress of their Work
With true delight observ'd 'em all
Raking up mudd to build a Wall
The Plan he much admir'd and took
The Model in his Table-book
Thought himself now exactly Skill'd
And So resolv'd a House to build
A real house with rooms & Stairs
Five times at least as big as theirs
Taller than Misses by two yards
Not a Sham thing of Clay or Cards
And So he did for in a while
He built up Such a monstrous Pile
That no Two Chairmen could be found
Able to lift it from the Ground
Stil at Whitehall it Stands in view
Just in the Place where first it grew
There all the little Schoolboys run
Envying to see themselves outdone
From Such deep rudiments as these
Van is become by due degrees
For building fam'd & justly reckon'd
At Court Vitruvius the Second,
No Wonder! Since wise authors shew,
That best Foundations Should be low,
And now the Duke has wisely ta'ne him
To be his Architect at Blenheim
But raillery for once apart,
If this rule holds in ev'ry art,
Or if his Grace were no more Skill'd in
The Art of Battring Walls than Building
We might expect to find next Year
A Mouse-Trapman Chief Engineer.086-632L
